name: Crans-Montana
subtitle: Alpine Paradise in the Swiss Alps
short_description: A sun-drenched plateau in the heart of the Swiss Alps offering stunning mountain views, outdoor activities, and sophisticated lifestyle.
description:
Crans-Montana is perched on a sun-drenched plateau high above the Rhone Valley, offering breathtaking views of the Swiss and French Alps. This dual municipality combines the best of alpine tradition with cosmopolitan sophistication.

In winter, Crans-Montana transforms into a premier ski destination with over 140 kilometers of varied slopes, while summer brings endless opportunities for hiking, mountain biking, and golf on the legendary Severiano Ballesteros course.

Beyond outdoor activities, Crans-Montana is known for its upscale shopping along the Rue du Prado, diverse culinary scene ranging from traditional Swiss cuisine to international gastronomy, and a vibrant cultural calendar including the Caprices Festival and the Omega European Masters golf tournament.

highlights.title: Alpine Panorama
highlights.description: Enjoy breathtaking views of iconic peaks including the Matterhorn, Mont Blanc, and the Bernese Alps from the sun-drenched plateau.

highlights.title: World-Class Golf
highlights.description: Play on the legendary Severiano Ballesteros golf course, home to the Omega European Masters tournament.

highlights.title: Year-Round Adventure
highlights.description: From winter skiing on 140km of slopes to summer hiking, mountain biking, and paragliding, Crans-Montana offers endless outdoor activities.

activities.title: Alpine Skiing
activities.description: Explore 140km of varied ski runs suitable for all levels, from gentle beginners' slopes to challenging black runs and off-piste terrain.

activities.title: Cross-Country Skiing
activities.description: Glide through snowy forests and across the plateau on 15km of groomed cross-country tracks.

activities.title: Golf
activities.description: Play on the Severiano Ballesteros course with its breathtaking Alpine views and challenging layout.

activities.title: Mountain Biking
activities.description: Ride through diverse terrain on over 200km of marked mountain bike trails for all skill levels.

activities.title: Hiking
activities.description: Discover over 300km of hiking trails through Alpine meadows, forests, and mountain landscapes.

activities.title: Paragliding
activities.description: Experience the thrill of soaring above the Alps with tandem paragliding flights available for all experience levels.

activities.title: Forest Walks
activities.description: Enjoy the spectacular autumn colors on forest walks around the lakes and through ancient pine forests.

dining.name: LeMontBlanc
dining.description: Sophisticated Alpine cuisine with a modern twist, featuring locally-sourced ingredients and an impressive wine list.

dining.name: Chetzeron
dining.description: Located in a converted cable car station at 2,112m altitude, offering panoramic views and contemporary mountain cuisine.

dining.name: La Marmotte
dining.description: Traditional Swiss restaurant specializing in raclette, fondue, and other local specialties in a cozy, rustic atmosphere.

signature_dishes.name: Raclette
signature_dishes.description: Traditional Swiss dish of melted cheese scraped onto potatoes, pickles, and dried meats.

signature_dishes.name: Alpine Lamb
signature_dishes.description: Locally-raised lamb with mountain herbs, seasonal vegetables, and potato gratin.

signature_dishes.name: Tartiflette
signature_dishes.description: Savory dish of potatoes, reblochon cheese, lardons, and onions baked to perfection.

chef_spotlight.name: Thomas Meyer
chef_spotlight.description: Chef Thomas Meyer combines traditional Swiss techniques with modern influences, focusing on seasonal and locally-sourced ingredients from the Valais region.

travel_info.title: Getting There
travel_info.description: Crans-Montana is accessible by car or public transport. The nearest international airports are Geneva (180km) and Zurich (300km). From Geneva, take the train to Sierre and then the funicular or bus to Crans-Montana.

travel_info.title: Climate
travel_info.description: Crans-Montana enjoys a microclimate with over 300 days of sunshine per year. Winter temperatures range from -5°C to 5°C, while summer temperatures typically range from 15°C to 25°C.

travel_info.title: Best Time to Visit
travel_info.description: For skiing, visit from December to April. For hiking and golf, June to September offers ideal conditions. September and October provide beautiful autumn colors with mild temperatures.

travel_info.title: Language
travel_info.description: The main language is French, though German and Italian are also official languages of Switzerland. English is widely spoken in tourist areas.

travel_info.title: Currency
travel_info.description: The Swiss Franc (CHF) is the official currency. Credit cards are widely accepted, but having some cash is recommended for smaller establishments.

weather.description: Cold temperatures with regular snowfall, creating excellent conditions for winter sports. The high altitude and north-facing slopes preserve snow quality.
Mild temperatures with occasional rainfall. Spring brings blooming Alpine flowers and the first hiking opportunities as snow melts at lower elevations.
Warm, sunny days with cool evenings. Summer offers ideal conditions for outdoor activities with occasional afternoon thunderstorms.
Mild temperatures with spectacular foliage colors. Autumn is less crowded and offers clear visibility for enjoying mountain views.

name: Dolomites
subtitle: The Pale Mountains of Northern Italy
short_description: A UNESCO World Heritage site featuring distinctive limestone peaks, alpine meadows, and a unique blend of Italian and Austrian cultures.
description:
The Dolomites are a mountain range in northeastern Italy, part of the Southern Limestone Alps. Named after the carbonate rock dolomite, these mountains are characterized by their pale color and distinctive shapes, with vertical walls and sharp pinnacles that create one of the most dramatic mountain landscapes in the world.

Recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, the Dolomites span across several Italian provinces and feature 18 peaks that rise above 3,000 meters. The region offers world-class skiing in winter as part of the Dolomiti Superski area, while summer brings opportunities for hiking, climbing, mountain biking, and paragliding.

The Dolomites also represent a fascinating cultural crossroads where Italian, Austrian, and Ladin influences blend in the architecture, cuisine, and local traditions of the charming mountain villages that dot the valleys.

highlights.title: Dramatic Limestone Peaks
highlights.description: Marvel at the distinctive pale mountains with their vertical walls and sharp pinnacles that create one of the world's most iconic mountain landscapes.

highlights.title: Cultural Crossroads
highlights.description: Experience the unique blend of Italian, Austrian, and Ladin cultures reflected in the architecture, cuisine, and traditions of the region.

highlights.title: Outdoor Paradise
highlights.description: From world-class skiing to hiking, climbing, and mountain biking, the Dolomites offer endless opportunities for outdoor adventures in every season.

activities.title: Dolomiti Superski
activities.description: Access 1,200km of ski runs across 12 interconnected resorts with a single ski pass in the world's largest ski circuit.

activities.title: Sella Ronda
activities.description: Ski the famous 26km circuit around the Sella massif, connecting four Dolomite valleys and passes.

activities.title: Alta Via Trails
activities.description: Hike the high-altitude trails that traverse the Dolomites, offering stunning views and mountain hut accommodation.

activities.title: Via Ferrata
activities.description: Follow protected climbing routes with fixed cables and ladders that make challenging terrain accessible to moderately experienced hikers.

activities.title: Mountain Biking
activities.description: Ride hundreds of kilometers of marked trails from gentle valley routes to challenging single-track descents.

activities.title: Photography Tours
activities.description: Capture the magical light of the Dolomites as it transforms the pale mountains into glowing pink and orange during the 'enrosadira' phenomenon.

dining.name: Rifugio Averau
dining.description: Mountain hut restaurant at 2,413m offering traditional cuisine with panoramic views of the surrounding peaks.

dining.name: St. Hubertus
dining.description: Three Michelin-starred restaurant focusing on local mountain ingredients with an innovative approach.

dining.name: Baita Fraina
dining.description: Family-run mountain restaurant serving traditional Ampezzo cuisine in a rustic setting.

signature_dishes.name: Canederli
signature_dishes.description: Bread dumplings served in broth or with butter, often flavored with speck (smoked ham) or cheese.

signature_dishes.name: Speck Alto Adige
signature_dishes.description: Locally-produced smoked and cured ham, a specialty of South Tyrol.

signature_dishes.name: Strangolapreti
signature_dishes.description: Spinach and bread 'priest strangler' dumplings served with brown butter and sage.

chef_spotlight.name: Norbert Niederkofler
chef_spotlight.description: Chef Niederkofler's 'Cook the Mountain' philosophy celebrates local, seasonal ingredients from the Dolomites, earning his restaurant three Michelin stars.

travel_info.title: Getting There
travel_info.description: The Dolomites are accessible by car or public transport. The nearest airports are Venice, Innsbruck, and Verona. Regional trains connect to towns like Bolzano and Cortina d'Ampezzo, from where bus services reach smaller villages.

travel_info.title: Climate
travel_info.description: The Dolomites have an Alpine climate with cold, snowy winters and mild summers. Winter temperatures range from -10°C to 0°C, while summer temperatures typically range from 10°C to 25°C.

travel_info.title: Best Time to Visit
travel_info.description: For skiing, visit from December to April. For hiking and climbing, mid-June to September offers the most reliable weather. Late September and October provide beautiful autumn colors with fewer crowds.

travel_info.title: Language
travel_info.description: Italian is the main language, though German is widely spoken in South Tyrol. In some valleys, Ladin (an ancient Romance language) is still spoken. English is common in tourist areas.

travel_info.title: Currency
travel_info.description: The Euro (€) is the official currency. Credit cards are widely accepted in towns and larger establishments, but cash is recommended for mountain huts and smaller restaurants.

weather.description: Cold temperatures with significant snowfall, creating excellent conditions for winter sports. The Dolomites typically have reliable snow conditions from December through April.
Variable conditions with snow still present at higher elevations. Lower valleys begin to bloom with spring flowers, while hiking season gradually begins in late spring.
Mild temperatures ideal for hiking and climbing. Afternoon thunderstorms are common, particularly in July and August, so morning activities are recommended.
Cooling temperatures with spectacular foliage as the larch trees turn golden. Early autumn offers stable weather and fewer crowds, while late autumn may see the first snowfall.
